p: Our results show that if no other measures had been implemented after the outbreak-control holiday, as we assumed in this study, the epidemic spread after the holiday could have returned to the trajectories of nearly exponential growth that were observed before the holiday. That is, an outbreak-control holiday, which mainly enhances social distancing for a finite period of time, should not be expected to be sufficient for epidemic control. Rather, it can merely serve to slow down transmission for some time. This finding indicates that, once an outbreak-control holiday ends and the economy reopens, second-waves are likelyâ€”unless people continue preventive measures, such as working from home and maintaining physical distance and wearing masks when outside the home [35].
